Use the table to answer the question below.

Price of Candy Bar

Quantity Supplied

<math alttext="$2.00" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>$</mi><mn>2.00</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
775 
100 

<math alttext="$4.00" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>$</mi><mn>4.00</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

250 

<math alttext="$5.00" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>$</mi><mn>5.00</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> 
525 
525 

<math alttext="$6.00" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>$</mi><mn>6.00</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> 
375 
700 

<math alttext="$7.00" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>$</mi><mn>7.00</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
200 
975 

<math alttext="$8.00" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>$</mi><mn>8.00</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
50 
1200 

When the price of a candy bar is <math alttext="$6.00" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>$</mi><mn>6.00</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, which of the following is true?

choices.label: The market does not clear because the price is lower than the equilibrium price and there will be a surplus in the market.
The market does not clear because the price is lower than the equilibrium price and there will be a shortage in the market.
The market clears because buyers and sellers are in agreement on the price.
The market does not clear because the price is higher than the equilibrium price and there will be a surplus in the market.
The market does not clear because the price is higher than the equilibrium price and there will be a shortage in the market.

content.answer: The market does not clear because the price is higher than the equilibrium price and there will be a surplus in the market.

topic.text: 1.6: Market Equilibrium, Disequilibrium, and Changes in Equilibrium

skill.text: Skill 2.C: Interpret a specific economic outcome using quantitative data or calculations.
